I wasn't sure whenever to post this in the Linux or DOS section.  

However, the following [reference](http://sourceforge.net/forum/forum.php?forum_id=873405 "External link") is link to a project about to compile the Linux kernel into a executable for DOS (real DOS, in sense of MS-DOS or FreeDOS).  

This project is pretty absorbing, it shows how flexible Linux is, it runs on different hardware architectures, together with NT-based Windows (CoLinux) and now also as exe in DOS.  

Can this project be useful for anything related to 'boot anything from anywhere'?  

One example I can think of is to boot from a BIOS-supported device, to load a DOS device driver (foe example DOS USB driver) and to start Linux from a DOS-(but not BIOS)-supported device. I would be interested to see a whole distro including gui based uppon Linux.exe.  

Any other ideas for what Linux.exe could be useful?

forumNotes.author: mr_
forumNotes.content:
New idea...  

Linux.exe is theoretically quite handy. kexec can be used in order to fast reboot linux without going thought BIOS again. One limitation of kexec is that it can only chanboot other linux kernels but no other operating systems such as linux. On the other hand we have grub.exe and the possibility to start (almost?) any operating system from a bootable device supported by BIOS (or BIOS extender such as PLoP).  

If we can shutdown linux.exe and return to DOS this can be easy combined with starting grub.exe from DOS.  

The only technical unknown thing in this mulitbooting DOS, Windows, Linux scenario is to shutdown Windows and to return to grub.exe without going thought BIOS again. I think this hasn't been implemented yet.  

Yes, it's also already possible to use kexec to chainboot grub.exe directly, but this isn't working always [reliable](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7217 "External link"). It's still questionable whenever it is more reliable to shutdown linux.exe and to start grub.exe from DOS compared to using kexec from linux directly. However, it will be more easy to debug grub.exe inside pure DOS compared to from kexec/linux?  

Soon I will try to get my own linux.exe and tell you whenever I can chainboot grub.exe better then directly with kexec.  

(I've posted this already on the [kexec-mailing](http://lists.infradead.org/pipermail/kexec/2009-February/003223.html "External link") list without feedback.)

My guess about the supposed unreliability of kexec loading is that you had a problem with the specific Linux kernel in Ubuntu 8.04, possibly attempting to use in a console window with X running. Same thing happens if you try loading grub.exe from a GUI booted Win9x: ``` ****************************************************************************** *** Known Problems *** ****************************************************************************** 1. Running GRUB.EXE from a DOS box of Windows 9x/Me could hang the machine, especially for some systems with USB support. You may encounter the same problem when running GRUB.EXE through KEXEC under Linux. Note: You don't have to run GRUB.EXE from protected mode of Win9x, which could hang the machine; Instead, you usually want to run GRUB.EXE after you have done a "Restart the computer in MS-DOS mode", which is safe enough. ```
Not enough to mark kexec loading "unreliable", as I see it, simply non-working with some Linux kernels and/or some hardware and related drivers. The nice "linuxware" thingie appears to be something that can load a linux kernel from DOS. From it you anyway need kexec to load grub.exe. is "shutting it" and return to DOS possible at all? ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) The original release post is here: [http://lkml.org/lkml/2008/9/8/2](http://lkml.org/lkml/2008/9/8/2 "External link") I seem not able to find even one single line of documentatin about it on "home page": ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) [http://www.wolfmountaingroup.org/](http://www.wolfmountaingroup.org/ "External link")
